The ordinary printed texts (Achillini’s edition) insert here two chapters from the Hebrew translation of the Western version which will be found on pp. 173-4. The first gives a different theory of Alchemy, the second describes a magic ring. They are not found in any Arabio text that 1 know of. Achillini also removed section P from its place and printed it before this Section.

From this point to the end of the section is the famous Emerald Table of Hermes, which appears here in its earliest known form. It has every appearance of considerable antiquity and is probably of Egyptian origin, passing through Byzantine treatiseS. There are several distinct translations of it current, but this is probably the best, as it is, on the whole, the simplest. The Arabic text appears to have received some additions. q

The following are some of the forms in which it is found :

1. Veritas ita se habet et non est dubium. Verum sine mendacio certum et verissimum. Verum est et ab omni mendaciorum involucro remotum. Vere non ficte, certo verissimeque aio.
